entries.text: We are a fast growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications. We have been hiring great Developers for many years, and we want to further expand our distributed team of talented and friendly Developers. Most of our experienced Developers telecommute; on-site positions are also available.
entries.title: We are Hiring a Senior Perl Software Developer - Grant Street Group

entries.text: Planning to attend the Swiss Perl Workshop? Now might be a good time to register, as the event is drawing close...

entries.text: Curious to know what are the cities in the race to host next year's YAPC::EU? Well, don't waste any time, click the link already!
entries.title: Where will YAPC::Europe 2015 take place?

entries.text: Dan Wright warns us that the Perl 5 Core Maintenance Fund is running low on gas. Companies that rely on Perl to do the job, now would be a good time to chip in...
entries.title: P5CMF Needs some love

entries.text: Makoto Nozaki gives us the low-down on the Perl Foundation Grants Committee; how much money they currently have, how the rest of the year looks like.
entries.title: Grants Committee Budget

entries.text: Need Perl training, and willing to help TPF at the same time? Gabor Szabo has a proposition for you.
entries.title: Perl Training and donation to TPF

entries.text: Dave Cross lets us know what's coming up at the London.pm meetings. (sneak peak: lots of good stuff, that's what is coming)
entries.title: London Perl Mongers Meeting

entries.text: the site's statistics, he draws a list of his best hits, as well as his own favorite entries.
entries.title: Seven years of blogging

entries.title: I went to YAPC::NA in Orlando!

entries.text: YAPC::NA is over, long live YAPC::EU. Alex Balhatchet and a contingent of Nestoria's devs are preparing themselves for the trip to Sofia, Bulgaria.
entries.title: See you at YAPC::EU!

entries.text: Neil Bowers testify of the synergy between CPAN authors, and how  we are more as a group than the sum of our parts.
entries.title: Community: helping each other

entries.text: Steven Haryanto gathers some interesting stats on Debian packages and the languages in which they are based.
entries.title: Some statistics from Debian package tags

entries.text: Andrew Solomon interviews Emma Howson, a young, nascent Perl developer (and author of the PerlAdventures blog which appears here from time to time).
entries.title: Why Learn Perl? Interview 4 - Emma Howson, Graduate and Emerging Perl Dancer

entries.text: Perl's new postderef syntax looks funny, but there is a reason for it. Aristotle explains  the devil that lies in the details of the deadly dereferencing drama.
entries.title: The perversity of traditional Perl's dereferencing syntax

entries.text: Using Interchange for your e-commerce? You might want to keep an eye on Stefan Hornburg, as he's starting a project that will allow Interchange to interface with Amazon and Ebay.
entries.title: Amazon & Ebay

entries.text: gvl has problems reaching metabase.cpantesters.org. From the comments, it seems that the problem isn't with the server, but could be born out of an IO::Socket::IP bug.
entries.title: Metabase down?

entries.text: chenryn has a stab at porting rspec, a type of testing framework to  ensure a host's configuration conforms to what is expected, to Perl.
entries.title: Rex meet Rspec

entries.text: Ovid offers us the first draft of a cruft-busting tool that aims to detect variables that are pushed to the templates but never used.
entries.title: Finding unused variables in your Template stash

entries.text: Mark Fowler announces a new version of Test::DatabaseRow. With the next version comes an easier way to tell the tests to open wide the gates of verbosity.
entries.title: Tell me more, tell me more

entries.text: Steven Haryanto compares modules producing text-based tables. And yes, some metrics are presented in text-based tables themselves. Yo dawg.
entries.title: Benchmarking several ASCII-table-generator modules

entries.text: Yanick plays around with a proxying service to manage his herd of sporadically-used toy web applications.
entries.title: A Ringleader Proxy for Sporadically-Used Web Applications

entries.text: "Parse HTML? Easy, let me write a regex!" NO! Stop right there, and go read David Farell's tricks and recommendations to sanely parse HTML instead. Trust me, you'll thank me later.
entries.title: HTML pro-parsing tips

entries.text: Laurent Dami continues on his quest for Perl-based virtual table support for SQLite. This time around, he has a working prototype to share with us.
entries.title: Perl virtual tables for DBD::SQLite : ready to test

entries.text: Tiny::Type is still too sluggish for you? You're mad. And so is Toby Inkster, who wrote a XS version of the module that gives a 300% boost to an already lean speed demon.
entries.title: Because Sometimes Lightspeed is Too Slow

entries.text: Joel Berger raves about the new features of Mojolicious, and of the doors they open (or, at least, make much easier to pass through).
entries.title: Non-blocking Mojolicious apps are even easier now!

entries.title: Fun with image transformations in Perl

header: This week, we have echos of the next conferences coming out way (YAPC::EU, the Perl Swiss Workshop, the next London.pm meetings). We also have some updates of the financial state of some of Perl's foundations and, alas without surprises, it seems we are running on a very lean budget -- perhaps a reminder to us all to poke our $workplaces and see if they can't help in some way to keep the ecosystem alive and well-fed. ~ `/anick
subject: There Be Cobwebs In Those Coffers
